articles.headline: A Campaign Retools to Seek Second Clinton Comeback
articles.snippet: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have never faced a scrape quite like Tuesday’s New Hampshire primary, when their would-be dynasty will be on the line.
articles.abstract: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have never faced a scrape quite like Tuesday’s New Hampshire primary, when their would-be dynasty will be on the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been in career-threatening scrapes before, but never quite like the one they face in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, when nothing less than their would-be dynasty will be on the line.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Daring to Believe, Blacks Savor Obama Victory
articles.snippet: African-Americans voiced pride and amazement over Senator Barack Obama’s victory in Iowa, with some seeing the result as a signal moment in race relations.
articles.abstract: African-Americans voiced pride and amazement over Senator Barack Obama’s victory in Iowa, with some seeing the result as a signal moment in race relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Sadou Brown in a Los Angeles suburb, the decisive victory of Senator Barack Obama in Iowa was a moment to show his 14-year-old son what is possible.

articles.headline: Warner Backs Blu-ray, Tilting DVD Battle
articles.snippet: Hollywood’s squabble over which of two technologies will replace standard DVDs skewed in the direction of Sony Corporation on Friday, with Warner Brothers casting the deciding vote.
articles.abstract: Hollywood’s squabble over which of two technologies will replace standard DVDs skewed in the direction of Sony Corporation on Friday, with Warner Brothers casting the deciding vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The high-definition DVD war is all but over.

articles.headline: McCain May Benefit From Huckabee’s Jolt to G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Out of the turmoil facing the Republican field may rise another opportunity for Senator John McCain.
articles.abstract: Out of the turmoil facing the Republican field may rise another opportunity for Senator John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabee’s defeat of Mitt Romney in the Iowa caucuses jolted a Republican Party establishment already distressed about the state of its presidential field.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Noontime Web Video Revitalizes Lunch at Desk
articles.snippet: For Web video, lunchtime has become the new prime time, and media companies have started responding.
articles.abstract: For Web video, lunchtime has become the new prime time, and media companies have started responding.
articles.lead_paragraph: In cubicles across the country, lunchtime has become the new prime time, as workers click aside their spreadsheets to watch videos on YouTube, news highlights on CNN.com or other Web offerings.

articles.headline: In Race for Gossip, TV Shows Turn to Blogs
articles.snippet: Competition to publish the nastiest, most breathless and up-to-the-moment celebrity gossip has always been fierce, but the Internet has pushed it to a new level.
articles.abstract: Competition to publish the nastiest, most breathless and up-to-the-moment celebrity gossip has always been fierce, but the Internet has pushed it to a new level.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are Joel and Nicole splitting up? Will Britney get her babies back? OmiGOD!

articles.headline: Fears on Inflation and Jobs Give 2008 a Stumbling Start
articles.snippet: When the closing bell rang on Friday, the Dow Jones industrials had fallen 256.54 points, nearly 2 percent, to 12,800.18.
articles.abstract: When the closing bell rang on Friday, the Dow Jones industrials had fallen 256.54 points, nearly 2 percent, to 12,800.18.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fears that a recession is imminent  or perhaps has already begun  rocked the major stock markets this week as anxiety-addled investors staggered through the first days of 2008.

articles.headline: Put Buyers First? What a Concept
articles.snippet: As the case of Amazon.com reveals, maybe taking care of customers is something worth doing when you are trying to create a lasting company.
articles.abstract: As the case of Amazon.com reveals, maybe taking care of customers is something worth doing when you are trying to create a lasting company.
articles.lead_paragraph: My Christmas story  the one I’ve been telling and retelling these last 10 days  began on Friday, Dec. 21.

articles.headline: In Chinese Factories, Lost Fingers and Low Pay
articles.snippet: Worker abuse is still commonplace in many of the Chinese factories that supply Western companies, according to labor rights groups.
articles.abstract: Worker abuse is still commonplace in many of the Chinese factories that supply Western companies, according to labor rights groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  Nearly a decade after some of the most powerful companies in the world  often under considerable criticism and consumer pressure  began an effort to eliminate sweatshop labor conditions in Asia, worker abuse is still commonplace in many of the Chinese factories that supply Western companies, according to labor rights groups.

articles.headline: Unemployment Sounds Warning About Economy
articles.snippet: Economists viewed a surge in unemployment as the most powerful sign to date of a possible recessionary downturn.
articles.abstract: Economists viewed a surge in unemployment as the most powerful sign to date of a possible recessionary downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate surged to 5 percent in December as the economy added a meager 18,000 jobs, the smallest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported on Friday.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Private Cash Sets Agenda for Urban Infrastructure
articles.snippet: Private spending, supported by a growing number of very wealthy families, is gaining ground on public investment.
articles.abstract: Private spending, supported by a growing number of very wealthy families, is gaining ground on public investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN  Conceived as a freeway, the Route 34 Connector still promises to whisk motorists across New Haven as they exit Interstate 95. But in less than a mile, the three broad lanes abruptly end, forcing traffic onto side roads that skirt the unbuilt right-of-way  a wasteland of elongated asphalt parking lots and scrub grass.

articles.headline: Can Burt’s Bees Turn Clorox Green?
articles.snippet: Another small, eco-friendly business is scooped up by a corporation.
articles.abstract: Another small, eco-friendly business is scooped up by a corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 1984, Burt Shavitz, a beekeeper in Maine, picked up Roxanne Quimby, a 33-year-old single mother down on her luck, as she hitchhiked to the post office in Dexter, Me. More than a dozen years Ms. Quimby’s senior, the guy locals called “the bee-man” sold honey in pickle jars from the back of his pickup truck. To Ms. Quimby, he seemed to be living an idyllic life in the wilderness (including making his home inside a small turkey coop).

articles.headline: At Debate, Two Rivals Go After Defiant Clinton
articles.snippet: John Edwards and Senator Barack Obama attacked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as never before.
articles.abstract: John Edwards and Senator Barack Obama attacked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as never before.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It was as if they sensed vulnerability.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Testing Investors’ Faith in State Street
articles.snippet: Now seems a peculiar time for shareholders to suspend their disbelief about the full impact the continuing credit crisis might have on financial services stocks.
articles.abstract: Now seems a peculiar time for shareholders to suspend their disbelief about the full impact the continuing credit crisis might have on financial services stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORCED over the last five months to face icky truths about the credit crisis, investors seem to believe we are near the end of a disturbing interlude. How else to explain the 8.2 percent rally last Thursday in shares of the State Street Corporation after it said it would seek fresh capital and add $618 million in reserves to cover lawsuits over subprime mortgage investments it made for some clients?

articles.headline: In This Race, Independents Are the Prize
articles.snippet: The presidential race is for the next few days largely in the hands of voters who identify with neither party.
articles.abstract: The presidential race is for the next few days largely in the hands of voters who identify with neither party.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H.  The race for president, steeped in appeals to each party’s base for nearly a year, is for the next few days largely in the hands of voters who identify themselves as neither Republican nor Democrat.

articles.headline: Harry Macklowe’s $6.4 Billion Bill
articles.snippet: Trouble in the commercial real estate market squeezes a Manhattan developer.
articles.abstract: Trouble in the commercial real estate market squeezes a Manhattan developer.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN August 2003, Harry B. Macklowe raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building, the 50-story commercial skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan that is one of New York’s trophy properties.
articles.byline: By Charles V. Bagli and Terry Pristin

articles.headline: Sharp Clashes in Hectic Days Before Primary
articles.snippet: The presidential candidates rushed into a final weekend of compressed and often harsh campaigning as they presented new themes to New Hampshire voters.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidates rushed into a final weekend of compressed and often harsh campaigning as they presented new themes to New Hampshire voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The presidential candidates rushed into a final weekend of compressed and often harsh campaigning here Saturday, as they presented new themes to New Hampshire voters and tried to keep pace with a schedule that left little room for error before the primary on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Investors Said to Seek a Takeover of CNet
articles.snippet: A group of investment funds has amassed a 21 percent stake in CNet and is seeking to oust its directors and take over a majority of its board.
articles.abstract: A group of investment funds has amassed a 21 percent stake in CNet and is seeking to oust its directors and take over a majority of its board.
articles.lead_paragraph: CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies, would typically write about all the gossip and speculation at the Consumer Electronics Show this week in Las Vegas. Now, however, the company is likely to be the one talked about.

articles.headline: Filling Big Hiking Boots at an Early Age
articles.snippet: Discovery Kids pins some hopes on a chip off the crocodile hunter.
articles.abstract: Discovery Kids pins some hopes on a chip off the crocodile hunter.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, Bindi Irwin was an 8-year-old growing up in the Australian outback, home-schooled so she could travel with her father, Steve Irwin, to film popular nature shows like “The Crocodile Hunter.” She sometimes appeared on camera, happily petting the occasional wallaby.

articles.headline: Publishing That’s All About Me
articles.snippet: Torn between family photos and a stack of periodicals.
articles.abstract: Torn between family photos and a stack of periodicals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, I boarded an airplane, one of the last gated communities for major media. Up there  for the most part  there is no e-mail, no YouTube, no cellphone. Just me, my 11-year-old daughter in the bulkhead seat next to me and a stack of newspapers and magazines.

articles.headline: Economists Say Movie Violence Might Temper the Real Thing
articles.snippet: A new study challenges conventional wisdom,  suggesting that violent films prevent violent crime by attracting and keeping would-be assailants occupied.
articles.abstract: A new study challenges conventional wisdom,  suggesting that violent films prevent violent crime by attracting and keeping would-be assailants occupied.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Are movies like “Hannibal” and the remake of “Halloween,” which serve up murder and mutilation as routine fare, actually making the nation safer?

articles.headline: Voter ID Laws Are Set to Face a Crucial Test
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will hear arguments that an Indiana law prevented voters from having their ballots counted.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments that an Indiana law prevented voters from having their ballots counted.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS  In April 2006, a federal judge upheld Indiana’s law on voter identification, the strictest in the nation, saying there was no evidence that it would prevent any voter from having his ballot counted.

articles.headline: Retracing His Steps, McCain Is Feeling Rejuvenated
articles.snippet: John McCain, who won the New Hampshire primary in 2000, is in many ways a different candidate now.
articles.abstract: John McCain, who won the New Hampshire primary in 2000, is in many ways a different candidate now.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign wheeled out a confetti gun on Saturday in Peterborough to boom a festive end to his 100th town-hall-style meeting. It was the same place he began his New Hampshire primary campaign of 2000.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Foiling U.S. Plan, Prison Expands in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Efforts to scale back the U.S. detention center at the Bagram military base are failing, and its conditions have drawn a strong complaint from the Red Cross.
articles.abstract: Efforts to scale back the U.S. detention center at the Bagram military base are failing, and its conditions have drawn a strong complaint from the Red Cross.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Bush administration struggles for a way to close the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a similar effort to scale down a larger and more secretive American detention center in Afghanistan has been beset by political, legal and security problems, officials say.

articles.headline: As Electronics Show Grows, Some Scale Back
articles.snippet: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has become a challenging place to introduce new products.
articles.abstract: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has become a challenging place to introduce new products.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  People attending the Consumer Electronics Show, starting here on Monday, will encounter a crowded and noisy stage where technology companies from around the world unveil their latest wares.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: In New Hampshire, Bill Clinton Finds Less Spark
articles.snippet: Campaigning for his wife, Bill Clinton has been drawing sleepy crowds in the state that revived his 1992 bid.
articles.abstract: Campaigning for his wife, Bill Clinton has been drawing sleepy crowds in the state that revived his 1992 bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.H.  Is this what it would have been like had Elvis been reduced to playing Reno?

articles.headline: Kenya Kikuyus, Long Dominant, Are Now Routed
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of Kikuyus, the tribe of Kenya’s president, have fled because of ethnic violence.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of Kikuyus, the tribe of Kenya’s president, have fled because of ethnic violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAKURU, Kenya  Kenya’s privileged tribe is on the run.
